subsection.title: Building Fractions
subsection.p: Let's begin with a quick review of the steps for adding fractions in arithmetic. Recall that we can only simplify a sum of like fractions. To add or subtract fractions with unlike denominators, we must convert the fractions to equivalent forms with the same denominator.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: Building is an application of the fundamental principle of fractions, \blert{ \dfrac{a}{b} = \dfrac{a \cdot c}{b \cdot c}},~~~~~\text{if} ~~~c \not= 0 In words, this says that we can multiply the numerator and denominator of a fraction by the same (nonzero) quantity without changing the value of the fraction.

statement.p: What does it mean to build a fraction?

answer.p: To convert the fraction to an equivalent form with a larger denominator.

subsection.p: We can visualize the building process with diagrams. Here are pictures of the original fractions in our example, \dfrac{2}{3} and \dfrac{3}{4}.

Thirds and fourths are not like fractions -- they are not pieces of the same size. But if we can break up one-third and one-fourth into smaller pieces that are the same size, then we can combine all the pieces. This is what the LCD is for. We can break up both thirds and fourths into twelfths, as shown below.

We can see from the figure that \dfrac{2}{3} = \dfrac{8}{12} and \dfrac{3}{4} = \dfrac{9}{12}. Once we have written the fractions with the same denominator, they are like fractions and we can add them. This is what building fractions is all about.

subsection.title: Adding and Subtracting Unlike Fractions
subsection.p: We add or subtract algebraic fractions in the same way.

assemblage.title: To Add or Subtract Algebraic Fractions

ol.li: Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) for the fractions.
Build each fraction to an equivalent one with the LCD as denominator.
Add or subtract the resulting like fractions: Add or subtract their numerators, and keep the same denominator.
Reduce the sum or difference if necessary.

statement.p: What is the first step in adding or subtracting unlike fractions?

answer.p: Find the lowest common denominator (LCD) for the fractions.

subsection.title: Finding the Lowest Common Denominator
subsection.p: How can we find an LCD for fractions whose denominators are algebraic expressions?

assemblage.p: The lowest common denominator for two or more algebraic fractions is the simplest algebraic expression that is a multiple of each denominator.

subsection.p: The easiest case occurs when neither denominator can be factored. In that case, their LCD is just the product of the two expressions. For example, the LCD for the fractions \dfrac{6}{x} and \dfrac{x}{x-2} is x(x-2).

solution.p: Step 1 Find the LCD: The LCD is x(x-2).

Step 2 Build: We build each fraction to an equivalent one with denominator x(x-2). To find the building factors, we compare the given denominator with the desired LCD. The building factor for each fraction is the missing factor.
Step 4 Reduce: The numerator of this fraction cannot be factored, so the sum cannot be reduced.

statement.p: When can we multiply two denominators together to find their LCD?
How do we find the building factor for each fraction?

answer.p: Compare the given denominator with the desired LCD.

subsection.p: However, if the denominators contain any common factors, the simplest common denominator is not just the product of the two denominators. In this case we must first factor each denominator to find their LCD.

solution.p: The LCD is not 12a^3(18a) = 216a^4. It is true that 216 is a multiple of both 12 and 18, but it is not the smallest one! We can find a smaller common denominator by factoring each denominator. 12a^3 = \alert{2} \cdot \alert{2} \cdot 3 \cdot \alert{a} \cdot \alert{a} \cdot \alert{a} 18a = 2 \cdot \alert{3} \cdot \alert{3} \cdot a To find an expression that both 12a^3 and 18a divide into evenly, we need only enough factors to "cover" each of them separately. In this case two 2's, two 3's, and three a's are sufficient, so the LCD is \text{LCD} = \alert{2 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3 \cdot a \cdot a \cdot a} = 36a^3 You can check that 36a^3 is a multiple of both 12a^3 and 18a.

assemblage.title: Look Closer
assemblage.p: To find the LCD in , notice that for each factor, we chose the denominator with the most copies of that factor, and included them in the LCD. For example, 12a^3 has only one factor of 3, but 18a has two factors of 3, so we used two factors of 3 in the LCD.

ol.li: Factor each denominator completely, and arrange the factors in order.

li.p:
For each factor,
Which denominator has the most copies of that factor? Circle them. (If there is a tie, either denominator will do.)
Include all the circled factors in the LCD.

ol.li: Multiply together the factors of the LCD.

statement.p: We would like to add two unlike fractions. If each denominator contains one factor of x, how many factors of do we include in the LCD?

subsection.p: Now let us see how to incorporate this new skill into the steps for adding fractions.

solution.p: Step 1 To find the LCD, we first factor each denominator completely. x^2-2x = x(x-2) x^2-4 = (x-2)(x+2) The LCD is x(x-2)(x+2).

Step 4 We reduce the fraction by first factoring numerator and denominator, then dividing out any common factors. \dfrac{x^2+2x-8}{x(x-2)(x+2)} = \dfrac{(x+4)\cancel{\blert{(x-2)}}}{x\cancel{\blert{(x-2)}}(x+2)} = \dfrac{x+4}{x(x+2)}

statement.p: State the four steps for adding or subtracting fractions.

answer.p: Find the LCD, build, combine, reduce.
